Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Nanoparticle Enhanced Near-IR Photobacterial Conversion of Organic Waste to Hydrogen

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria provide many useful functions in nature and in industrial sector ranging from degradation of wastes to production of methane to synthesis of pharmaceuticals. Some photo-active bacteria with proper food source and light activation can synthesize high-energy content fuel, such as, hydrogen. In addition, nanoparticles have lot of beneficial uses which range from transparent sunscreens to self-cleaning windows to smarter surfaces. This high risk-high payoff research project integrates nanotechnology, photoactive bacteria, and appropriate light source to convert waste organic acids to highly valuable clean energy. The transformative approach localizes light with enhanced intensity to maximize the production of hydrogen from waste organic acids. This EAGER award, with high impact in energy, environment and global economy involves the integration of photonics, biology, and nanostructured materials for clean fuel production.

The technical aspects of the project involve the combination of photoresponsive bacteria, plasmonic nanoparticles, and selective membranes to produce hydrogen from waste materials. The approach will involve the understanding of hydrogen production from purple non-sulfur bacteria (PNS) illuminated by light sources matched with bacteria's absorption spectrum. More specifically, it is expected that narrowband illumination of R. Palustris in the near-IR will enhance both hydrogen production and light conversion efficiency. The innovative approach employs nanoparticles with localized surface plasmon resonances immobilized on a polymer membrane surface to enhance the intensity and scattering of light. The research will establish that if the bacteria on top of the nanoparticles are immobilized with a thin dielectric layer in between, it will highly enhance the overall process efficiency. There is clearly a need for a "high risk-high reward" approach to dramatically increase light-conversion while maintaining high substrate- conversion efficiency with the goal of combined waste remediation and renewable energy generation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview 

This research project aimed to produce highly valuable fuel through nano-photo-bio based technology for both waste remediation and energy production Under this goal, we demonstrated enhanced hydrogen production using near-IR illumination as compared to a visible light source. The enhanced hydrogen production using near-IR illumination is attributable to the increased light absorption of photobacteria at near-IR wavelength. Our results also demonstrated enhanced hydrogen production from organic acids using optically resonant nanoparticles due to enhanced light intensity. Specifically, gold core-shell particles with resonances near the bacteria’s absorption maxima further improved hydrogen production compared to using near-IR light alone.

Intellectual Merit 

The proposed project was completed by integrating photoresponsive bacteria and plasmonic nanoparticles to increase the efficiency of producing hydrogen from waste materials.  The research yielded quantitative understanding of how incident light wavelength influences bacterial growth kinetics, hydrogen production and light conversion efficiency (LCE). We also determined the impact of plasmonic nanoparticles on the efficiency of hydrogen production. These nanoparticles with a hydrophilic coating had an insignificant impact on photobacterial viability.   

Broader Impacts:   

The technologies driven by this project have strong impacts on energy and the environment by enhancing light conversion efficiency for the conversion of organic wastes to clean fuels and fuel cell applications. The knowledge on near-IR light induced hydrogen production will also enhance the utilization of solar light for hydrogen production. Enhanced understanding of interface between nanoparticles and photo-responsive bacteria will further advance knowledge in interaction of nanomaterials with biological systems. This research sparked a highly significant collaboration with an energy company. Graduate and undergraduate students have been trained and exposed to a multidisciplinary field involving chemistry, electrical engineering, and chemical/environmental engineering.
